ui.title: üßÄ Chez Julien
ui.subtitle: A Brussels Cheese Shop Story
ui.introLine2: Will you build a neighborhood institution? Or burn out trying?
ui.introLine3: Every choice matters. Every month counts.

story.title: üìñ The Real Story Behind the Game
story.p1: Julien is a real person. In July 2022, he bought a struggling bulk food store in Woluwe-Saint-Pierre, Brussels, from Genevi√®ve‚Äîthe previous owner who was ready to retire. He started with almost nothing: no savings, just a dream of transforming this dying √©picerie into something special.
story.p2: The shop came with ‚Ç¨38,000 of "stock" on paper‚Äîquinoa from 2019, organic lentils that nobody wanted, cacao powder gathering dust. The √©picerie s√®che (dry goods) market was dying, down 23% industry-wide. But Julien saw what others didn't: the neighborhood needed a fromagerie.
story.p3: September 2023 brought Poncho‚Äîan Australian Shepherd with endless energy who became the shop's mascot. Customers came just to see him. Kids would visit daily. He forced Julien to take walks, which turned out to be the best stress relief.
story.p4: In November 2023, Madame Malfait (the landlord) called with news: she was selling the building. ‚Ç¨380,000 total, ‚Ç¨80,000 down payment needed by July 2024. Eight months to save what seemed impossible. The countdown began.
story.p5: July 2024: Against all odds, Julien bought the building. His hand trembled signing the papers. No more landlord. No more vulnerability. The shop was truly his.
story.p6: September 2024: Lucas joined the team‚Äîyoung, chaotic, passionate about food. He came from the shop next door and brought energy (sometimes too much). Then in early 2025, Lucas's friend Henry arrived‚Äîcalm, reliable, the perfect balance. Finally, Julien could delegate.
story.p7: The burnout was real. The Sunday question was real. The Swiss raclette trip, the December rushes, the AFSCA inspections‚Äîall real. This game is Julien's actual journey, compressed into 42 months.
story.p8: Every event in this game is based on something that actually happened.

items.def: Creamy sheep's milk cheese from southern France. Julien's first cheese.
Nutty aged cheese from Jura mountains. Comes in 8, 12, 18, 24+ months.
Melting cheese from Alps. Scraped onto potatoes. Winter essential.
"King of Cheeses." Italian hard cheese aged 24-72 months.
Spanish sheep's milk cheese. Firm, nutty, slightly tangy.
Classic French soft cheese. Creamy center, bloomy rind.
Small, creamy French cheese. Gets runnier as it ages.
Summer Beaufort. Alpine cheese made when cows graze high pastures.
Fresh goat cheese. Tangy, spreadable, doesn't keep long.
Buffalo milk mozzarella from Italy. Creamy, delicate, best fresh.
Cheeses washed in brine/alcohol. Pungent smell, rich flavor.
Cheese ager. Experts who mature cheese to perfection.
Belgian food safety agency. They do surprise inspections. Terrifying but necessary.
Organic food distributor. Thursday deliveries. Julien's main produce supplier.
Premium cheese wholesaler. Source of Tomme Larzac and many others.
Belgian cooperative for quality meats and charcuterie.
Brussels commune. Residential, family-oriented, where Chez Julien is located.
Famous weekly market in Ixelles. Wednesday afternoons.
Upscale shopping street in Ixelles. Has a wine shop Julien refers to.
"Dry grocery" - bulk foods, grains, pasta. The original shop concept.
Brussels has 19 communes (municipalities). Each is semi-autonomous.
Mulled wine. Essential at Christmas markets.
Cheese/charcuterie platters. Big business for events and corporate clients.
"Closed" - the sign you put up when taking a much-needed break.

end.subtitle_bankruptcy: The loans piled up. The interest crushed you.
end.subtitle_health: You gave everything. Your body said stop.
end.subtitle_relationships: The shop thrived. Everything else didn't.
end.story_completed_success_1: Three and a half years ago, you walked into a failing bulk shop. Today, {{shopName}} is a thriving destination.
end.story_completed_success_2_owned: You OWN the building. That ‚Ç¨80,000 scramble in 2024 was worth every stressed-out month.
end.story_completed_success_2_renting: You're still renting, but the business is solid.
end.story_completed_success_3_dog: Poncho greets customers at the door‚Äîtail wagging, full Aussie energy. He's become part of the brand.
end.story_completed_success_4_henry: Henry and Lucas run the shop when you're not there. You finally learned to let go.
end.story_completed_success_5_cheese: The pivot to cheese wasn't just a business decision‚Äîit was listening to what the neighborhood actually needed.
end.story_completed_success_5_niche: You found your niche. The neighborhood found their shop.
end.story_completed_survival_1: The shop survives. It's not the success story you imagined, but the doors stay open.
end.story_completed_survival_2_lowFamily: The cost was high. Some relationships didn't survive the journey.
end.story_completed_survival_2_okFamily: You managed to keep family close.
end.story_completed_survival_3: You learned what works and what doesn't. Maybe year four will be different.
end.story_bankruptcy_1: The loans kept growing. {{loan}} in debt at 8% monthly interest‚Äîthe math became impossible.
end.story_bankruptcy_2_liquidated: You tried to pivot, to adapt. It wasn't enough.
end.story_bankruptcy_2_no: Maybe liquidating that old stock earlier would have helped.
end.story_bankruptcy_3: The economy was brutal. The interest rates were predatory. Sometimes the deck is stacked against you.
end.story_bankruptcy_4: Failure isn't the end. It's data. You know things now that you couldn't have learned any other way.
end.story_suppliers_1: The cheese suppliers were patient. Once. Twice. Three times they waited for payment.
end.story_suppliers_2: But trust only stretches so far. When the fourth invoice went unpaid, the calls stopped. The deliveries stopped. The shop had nothing to sell.
end.story_suppliers_3: In retail, cash flow is oxygen. You ran out of air.
end.story_health_1_sunday: Opening Sundays seemed smart. Seven days a week, every week, for years‚Äîyour body couldn't sustain it.
end.story_health_1_nosunday: Even without Sundays, the load was too much.
end.story_health_2: The shop might survive. You needed to step back to survive yourself.
end.story_relationships_1: You built something. But the people who mattered weren't there to share it.
end.story_relationships_2: Success means nothing in an empty apartment.
end.lesson_sunday_burnout: Sunday opening led to burnout. Rest matters.
end.lesson_sunday_ok: Staying closed Sundays preserved your energy.
end.lesson_burnout_one: One burnout: stress has consequences. Max energy now {{cap}}%.
end.lesson_burnout_many: {{count}} burnouts! Your body paid the price. Max energy now {{cap}}%.
end.lesson_loan_brutal: Loans are brutal. {{loan}} in debt at 6% monthly interest compounds fast.
end.lesson_debt_free: Stayed debt-free. Cash flow management was key.
end.lesson_family_help: Asked family for help {{count}} time(s). Sometimes you need your people.
end.lesson_liquidated: Liquidating bad stock early freed up resources.
end.lesson_cheese_pivot: The pivot to cheese was the right call.
end.lesson_henry: Henry was the game-changer for work-life balance.
end.lesson_poncho: Poncho brought joy‚Äîand forced you to take walks. Sometimes that's what you need.
end.lesson_no_delegate: Not delegating enough kept you trapped.
end.lesson_building: Buying the building secured your future.
end.lesson_empire: You built an empire. Two shops, one vision.
end.lesson_contentment: You had the money to expand, but chose contentment. Wisdom.
end.lesson_producers: Producer visits built authenticity and stories.
end.lesson_parmigiano: Emilia-Romagna changed you. You understand cheese differently now.
end.lesson_birthday: That birthday party‚Äîeveryone saw what you'd built. Worth every moment of chaos.
end.lesson_reputation: Your reputation became your greatest asset. Word of mouth is powerful.
end.lesson_full_menu: Diversifying products created multiple revenue streams.

intro.narrative1: You signed the papers this morning.
intro.narrative2: A small bulk food shop. Organic pasta, quinoa, chia seeds.
intro.narrative3: The previous owner handed you the keys with a tired smile.
intro.narrative4: ‚Ç¨12,000 in savings. A dream. A risk.
intro.narrative5: What you build here is up to you.

cash_crisis.title: No More Grace
cash_crisis.dynamicDescription: You've used all 3 supplier grace periods. Now you're ‚Ç¨{{amount}} short and they won't wait anymore. You need to find money NOW or the shop closes.

choices.outcome: The bank approved your loan. The interest rate hurts‚Äî6% per month. But the suppliers get paid.

choices.hint: Lose some capacity but avoid debt
choices.outcome: You sold the backup fridge, some shelving. Got less than it was worth, but you avoided the debt spiral.

choices.hint: They'll help, but it costs something else
choices.outcome: Your family came through. They didn't ask for interest. But you saw the worry in their eyes. This weighs on the relationship.

sunday_opening.title: The Sunday Question
sunday_opening.description: Day one. The previous owner was closed Sundays. But you see other shops open. That's a great opportunity. More revenue, more visibility. But also: no days off. Only Mondays... This is your first big decision.

choices.hint: Could be up to 20% more revenue - substantial extra
choices.outcome: Sundays are busy. Not the busiest, but good. You now work 6 days a week. Only Mondays off.
You kept Sundays sacred. Your body thanks you. Your family sees you at least one day.

building_deadline.dynamicDescriptionCanAfford: The deadline is here. Your bank: ‚Ç¨{{bank}}. Required: ‚Ç¨80,000. You have enough. Barely. But you have enough.
building_deadline.dynamicDescriptionCannotAfford: The deadline is here. Your bank: ‚Ç¨{{bank}}. Required: ‚Ç¨80,000. You're short. But maybe there's still a way...

choicesCanAfford.outcome: You signed. Your hand trembled. The building‚ÄîYOUR building‚Äîis no longer someone else's. No landlord can ever push you out.
You chose not to buy. The building sold to someone else. You'll keep renting‚Äîbut also keep your savings and flexibility.

choicesCannotAfford.hint: Get one more month - ‚Ç¨5,000 penalty will be due after purchase
choicesCannotAfford.outcome: You begged Madame Malfait. She agreed‚Äîbut there's a ‚Ç¨5,000 penalty for the delay, due when the sale closes. One more month. Make it count.
You couldn't make the numbers work. The building sold to someone else. You'll keep renting. Keep vulnerable.

stock_reality.title: The Inventory
stock_reality.description: Two weeks in, you finally finish counting everything. The ‚Ç¨38,000 in stock on paper... doesn't match reality. Bulk quinoa from 2019. Organic lentils that smell strange. Cacao en poudre nobody wants. The √©picerie s√®che is dying‚Äîsales down 23% industry-wide. Realistically, maybe ‚Ç¨10,000 is sellable. The rest is just... there.

choices.text: Progressive liquidation - flea markets, deep discounts
choices.hint: It's going to be a lot of work...
choices.outcome: You spent weekends at flea markets. Bulk bins at -70%. The organic rice finally moved. Customers noticed you care. Space cleared for products people actually want‚Äîlike cheese.

choices.text: Find a "guy" to take the bulk stuff
choices.hint: Someone who buys dead stock, no questions asked
choices.outcome: A contact of a contact showed up with a van. Handed you ‚Ç¨1,500 for stuff worth ‚Ç¨10,000 wholesale. You didn't ask questions. Problem solved, but no lessons learned.

choices.text: Keep trying to sell it normally
choices.hint: Maybe customers will come around eventually?
choices.outcome: You kept the bulk bins. They gathered dust. Products expired. The smell drove customers away. Every month, you threw away more stock and more money.

shop_front.description: Chez Julien... chez moi, chez vous, chez mes potes!

team_photo.description: Julien, Lucas, and Henry - Santa hats mandatory

flood_disaster.description: Ankle-deep in the storage room. Insurance saved us.

poncho_grown.title: Poncho All Grown Up
poncho_grown.description: Still stealing hearts. Now from his favorite chair.

swiss_alps.description: Meeting the raclette makers in Valais. The cows, the mountains, the cheese.

building_keys.description: You own the building. No more rent.

burnout_recovery.title: The Recovery
burnout_recovery.description: You crashed. You came back. Stronger.

lucas_joins.title: Lucas Joins!
lucas_joins.description: Your first employee. He's already charming the customers with raclette samples.

busy_shop.title: The Rush
busy_shop.description: September chaos. The best kind of problem to have.

julien_cheese.title: Wine & Cheese
julien_cheese.description: The perfect pairing. Each bottle tells a story.

christmas_gifts.title: Christmas Gift Boxes
christmas_gifts.description: Handmade gift boxes with the special Chez Julien touch.

shop_party.title: La F√™te!
shop_party.description: When the shop becomes a party. Good vibes only.

poncho_surgery.title: The Cone of Shame
poncho_surgery.description: Too much cheese tasting! Poncho needed surgery. Lucia nursed him back to health.

lucia_christmas.title: Christmas Artist
lucia_christmas.description: Lucia painting the shop windows. Love is in the details.

family_visit.title: Family Support
family_visit.description: Your parents came to visit. Poncho approved.

parmigiano_dream.title: The Dream Trip
parmigiano_dream.description: Emilia-Romagna. The Parmigiano caves. A cheese lover's paradise.
